entry.title: A Beginners guide to SAP BDC
entry.content:
Many developers have contacted me in message box asking how to start with learning SAP BDC.

SAP Has provided many learning paths for same which are available on the Learning hub, but, what about people who don’t have access to learning hub or someone who is still working in legacy technologies.

Sharing these learning links hoping that this will help atleast a few people who trying to learn SAP BDC.

 

Core Components of SAP BDC system

Layer

Description

Source Systems

Includes SAP S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, and external systems. Data is bundled into entities like tables and views for replication.

Foundation Services

Harmonizes and transforms raw data into Data Products. These are stored in a hyperscaler environment (SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake files).

SAP Datasphere

Acts as the semantic layer. Defines data models, manages access control, and supports both prebuilt and custom analytical scenarios.

SAP Databricks

Embedded AI/ML engine for advanced analytics. Enables pro-code engineering and machine learning extensions.

SAP Analytics Cloud

Provides visualization, planning, and ad-hoc analysis capabilities. Powers dashboards and intelligent applications.

BDC Cockpit

Central hub for managing Data Products, Intelligent Applications, and data sharing workflows.

 

You must learn SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics cloud to be ready for SAP BDC.

 

You may use below link to learn more about SAP Datasphere.

Get Started with Your Trial in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials

This mission is the ideal starting point for newcomers to start using SAP Datasphere, get their trial account, and learn the fundamentals for modelling their data in SAP Datasphere.

This training will cover below activities.

  1. Get to Know the SAP Datasphere Interface | SAP Tutorials : talks about how to navigate the user interface of SAP Datasphere and what the home screen controls can do for you
  2. Add Users and Assign Roles in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to add users into your SAP Datasphere tenant, how to assign roles to users, How to edit users in bulk
  3. Create and Monitor a Space in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to create a Space and how to manage and monitor your Space
  4. Create an Entity Relationship Model in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about overview of E/R Models, how to create an E/R Model, how to associate data columns and how to finalise an E/R Model and deploy
  5. Create a Graphical View in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : talks about graphical views, how to create them, how to rename and restore columns in Graphical view and their deployment
  6. Define Measures and Add Business Information to a View | SAP Tutorials talks about what is semantic information, how to define measures, how to add business information, how to change business names of measures and attributes, how to change the semantic type of measures and attributes and how to preview your modelled dataset
  7. Generate Time Table and Dimensions | SAP Tutorials talks about how to create time tables and dimensions and how to associate the time dimensions with your data
  8. Upload Flat Files and Wrangle Your Data | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to upload flat files in the Data Builder of SAP Datasphere, how to make the best of the Data Builder capabilities during a file upload process and how to transform the data for data consistency and integrity
  9. Replicate Data into SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to check the type of data access, how to create a real time data replication and how to schedule the data replication
  10. Integrate and Monitor Data with SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to access the Data Integration Monitor, how to use the Data Integration Monitor dashboard and the types of monitoring you can do with the Data Integration Monitor

 

 

You can use below links to know more about SAP Analytics cloud.

  1. Exploring SAP Analytics Cloud
  2. Create a Live Data Connection in SAP Analytics Cloud | SAP Tutorials
  3. Create Live Data Model and a Story | SAP Tutorials
  4. Develop and Consume Queries on SAP Analytics Cloud | SAP Tutorials

SAP has basic trial versions for both SAP Datasphere and SAC where you may get some hands on knowledge to perform few activities.

Get started with Basic Trial | SAP Tutorials

 

Once you have a good understanding of SAP Datasphere and SAC, you can start going through SAP BDC learning paths.

Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud

 

You may also go through below blogs

SAP BDC for Dummies - SAP Community

SAP BDC Key Features - SAP Community

Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products - SAP Community

 

Happy Learning!

 

Swati Gawade-Shingade.

Cognizant technology Solutions.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in June
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in June

Another month with a great new release delivery ✨
Learn more in my short top features video in June 2025 on YouTube 📺
In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs.

 

 

My top features in June

 

SQL and Script Views as Source Objects for Your Replication Flows

You can create a replication flow with an SQL view or a script view as a source. Supported connections are SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA On-premise and SAP Datasphere. Initial only loads are currently supported, and you must define a primary key for your view to allow the deployment. 
➡️   More information

 

Python Version 3.11 available for Data Flows

The Data Flow script operator enables the Python version 3.11 for your data flows. When creating a data flow or modifying an existing one, you can now choose the new Python Version 3.11. Please note that Python 3.9 will reach its end-of-life soon, hence we recommend upgrading your data flows to 3.11 as the maintenance for 3.9 ends in October 2025. 
➡️   More information

 

New Data Types Supported for Local Tables (File)

We now support additional data types for local tables in the file space on the object store. You can now select the additional data types: DateTime, hana.BINARY and hana.TINYINT. 
➡️   More information

 

Object Store API calls

We separated API request calls from the compute in the flexible tenant configuration. That means you can now specify the number of API requests separately when configuring object storage. With the new option, you can define the expected number of API calls per month, giving you more control and accuracy in estimating your object storage needs. 
➡️   More information

 

 

My favorite blog in June

There is an excellent blog I want you to be aware of. My friend and co-author of multiple books @FrankRiesner wrote this blog about SAP BW PCE and explains what it is, and also what it is not.
➡️  Enjoy your read: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/what-exactly-is-sap-bw-pce-and-what-it-is-not/ba-p/14127149

entry.title: Automating Flat File Loads in SAP Datasphere Using Generic SFTP Connections
entry.content:
With Datasphere release 2025.11, SAP introduced a powerful new feature: the Generic SFTP Connection. This enhancement significantly simplifies and automates the process of loading flat files into Datasphere.
Traditionally, users had to manually upload each flat file, which was cumbersome especially when dealing with multiple files. Now, with Generic SFTP, the process can be fully automated using scripting (e.g., Python), resulting in faster and more efficient bulk data ingestion.

This blog walks you through a basic method to leverage the Generic SFTP connection as a source object in a Data Flow. File formats currently supported include:JSON, JSONL, CSV, XLS, XLSX, ORC, and PARQUET.

Key Benefits

  • Automates repetitive flat file loads
  • Supports bulk data ingestion
  • Can be orchestrated using SAP Integration Suite or custom scripts (e.g., Python)

Prerequisites

  1. Valid Generic SFTP Connection
  2. Source File Availability

Steps to Load Data from Generic SFTP

First, you need to create a Data Flow to handle how the data will be ingested when transferred to generic SFTP

  • Go to the "Sources" tab in the Data Builder. Expand the "Connections" folder, navigate to the SFTP connection, and select the folder containing the source file.

 

  • Drag and drop the file onto the canvas.
  • (Optional) Click "Modify" to edit columns if needed. You can rename, remove, or change data types.

  • Click the source node and choose "Add Table" to create a new target table.
  • Click "Create and Deploy Table".
  • Choose the appropriate load Mode:
    • Append – Add new records to existing data
    • Truncate – Clear existing data before loading
    • Delete – Remove existing records based on matching keys before loading
  • Run the Data Flow to load data into the target table.

Example Use Case: Automating Product Image Integration

Our organization leveraged the Generic SFTP Connections feature in SAP Datasphere to automate the integration of product image data into Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). Here's how the solution was implemented:

  • A third-party system generates a flat file containing Product IDs and corresponding image URLs every time a new product is added.
  • For the initial load, we used a Python script to transfer this file to the SFTP server. A Dataflow configured in Append mode then loaded the file into a target table in Datasphere.
  • To incorporate the image URLs into the data model, we extended the Product Master Data dimension in Datasphere by adding a new attribute for the image URL. The semantic type of this attribute was set to "Image URL".
  • This enhancement allowed seamless integration into existing SAC dashboards, enabling dynamic display of product images.
  • For ongoing daily updates, we scheduled the Dataflow to run automatically. SAP Integration Suite transfers the updated file to the same SFTP folder each day, using a consistent file name to support full automation.

End result

# Generic script to transfer file to SFTP Server
# Be sure to change the source file and destination folder name
import paramiko
import os
# === SFTP connection details ===
hostname = <enter SFTP host> 
port = 22  # Usually 22 for SFTP
username = <enter user name> 
password = <Enter password> 
# === Local file and remote folder ===
local_file_path = < Source File name with Path> 
remote_folder_path = <Target Destination>    # No filename, just the folder

def upload_file_sftp():
   try:
       # Extract just the filename
       filename = os.path.basename(local_file_path)
       remote_file_path = os.path.join(remote_folder_path, filename).replace('\\', '/')

       # Connect to SFTP
       transport = paramiko.Transport((hostname, port))
       transport.banner_timeout = 10  # Prevent timeout errors
       transport.connect(username=username, password=password)

       sftp = paramiko.SFTPClient.from_transport(transport)

       # Upload the file
       print(f"Uploading {local_file_path} to {remote_file_path}")
       sftp.put(local_file_path, remote_file_path)
       print("Upload successful.")
       sftp.close()
   transport.close()

   except Exception as e:
       print(f"Error occurred: {e}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
   upload_file_sftp()

Conclusion

This new feature drastically streamlined data ingestion pipelines and reduced manual effort for teams managing frequent flat file loads. By combining Datasphere’s Generic SFTP connections with automation scripts, organizations can achieve fully managed and scalable data pipelines

entry.title: The Future of Planning in Excel: The SAP Analytics Cloud Add-in as a Strategic Frontend – Part 1/3
entry.content:
Introduction

For many business users in finance and controlling, Microsoft Excel is more than just software — it’s the daily tool for analysis, reporting, and, above all, corporate planning. Its flexibility and familiar environment are unbeatable. But how do you combine this flexibility with the power, security, and scalability of a central planning platform like the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)?

The answer is the SAP Analytics Cloud Add-in for Microsoft Office. This modern add-in is positioned as the strategic successor to the proven SAP Analysis for Office, bridging the gap between the familiar world of Excel and the powerful in-memory planning engine of SAC.

A Quick Comparison: Analysis for Office vs. SAC Add-in

For anyone who has worked with SAP data in Excel for years, SAP Analysis for Office (AfO) is an old friend. It’s a robust and feature-rich tool, primarily designed for analyzing data from SAP BW and S/4HANA. It is based on traditional COM add-in technology and is heavily focused on querying BEx Queries or CDS Views.

The new SAC Add-in, on the other hand, was built from the ground up as a native frontend for the SAP Analytics Cloud. Here are the key differences and advantages at a glance:

  • Architecture: The SAC add-in is a modern Microsoft Office 365 add-in (based on WebView2). This allows for centralized, cloud-based deployment and management directly from the Microsoft Admin Center—without cumbersome client installations.
  • Connectivity: While AfO connects directly to backend systems like SAP BW, the primary and sole anchor point for the SAC add-in is your SAC tenant. All data, models, and permissions are sourced centrally from SAC.
  • Focus on Planning: The add-in is optimized for SAC planning models. Features like data entry, running data actions, version management, and using planning features are seamlessly integrated. You work in Excel but leverage the full power of the SAC planning engine in the background.
  • Future Strategy: SAP is clearly positioning the SAC add-in as the strategic tool for Excel integration in the cloud world.

The Architecture: Native Planning and „Seamless Integration“ into Datasphere

The true strength of the new approach lies in its seamless architecture. Instead of keeping planning data in separate silos, SAC allows for direct integration with SAP Datasphere.

This concept ensures that planning data entered in Excel via the SAC add-in can be written directly into the underlying structures of SAP Datasphere. The data flow remains consistent and is always controlled by SAC.

Architecture Diagram: Planning with the SAC Add-in
Architecture

Building an Interactive Planning Sheet

A simple data table is just the beginning, but the true strength of the add-in lies in the combination of SAC data and the flexibility of Excel. Our goal is not just to display data, but to design an interactive planning input screen.

1. Define a Clear Layout:

Using the „Builder“ panel, drag the required dimensions into the rows and columns.

 

2. Use Excel Formulas for Ad-Hoc Analysis:

This is the key advantage: you can use native Excel formulas right next to the data loaded from SAC. For example, add a sum column and calculate it with a simple formula like =SUM(C7:E7). This cell updates dynamically as soon as new plan data is entered or changed.

 

3. Add Data Action Triggers:

Currently the excel add in supports triggering Data Actions directly (Multi Actions are planned for Q4 2025).

 

 

That’s it for the first part of this blog series, stay tuned for more advanced/technical content in the next blog post.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere catalog - Harvesting from SAP BW/4HANA
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere introduced in 2023 advanced catalog functions aimed at making data more accessible and enhancing data-driven insights (initial announcement). This capability enables the management, organization and augmentation of metadata extracted from multiple SAP data sources. It aids in the discovery of curated data assets and lets users and data stewards search for and classify these assets. Additionally, the catalog allows to enhance assets with business metadata, supporting organizations in their data governance initiatives. Initially, it integrates with sources like SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Datasphere BW Bridge (feature overview), pulling metadata from various assets within these systems.

SAP BW/4HANA as a comprehensive data warehouse enriched with massive content of business logic and semantics is a crucial element for our customers to unlock the full potential of advanced analytics, machine learning and informed decision-making at scale.

We are very happy today to announce that we are expanding the coverage of SAP Datasphere catalog metadata harvesting with the support of SAP BW/4HANA allowing our customers to run accurate, contextualized, and trustworthy data analysis.

Configuring Connection to SAP BW/4HANA

​First let’s have a look at how we configure SAP Datasphere to connect and retrieve metadata from a SAP BW/4HANA system. This will require to create a live connection as well as reuse this live connection to create a remote system connection entry point for the catalog. Let's start by creating the live connection.

Click System and then Configuration.

In the Data Integration tab, you need to create a live data connection of type tunnel to the SAP BW/4HANA system to import the assets metadata. This live connection can be further reused either in Space Management to import models in modeller or in the remote systems for the metadata extractions for the catalog.

Click "Manage Live Data Connections".

Click "+" to create a new live connection, this will guide you to create this connection with a wizard-like experience.

This will require to fill in the following mandatory information:

  • Host URL
  • HTTPS Port
  • Client Id
  • User Name and Password

Once this live connection is created, we can now directly use it to create a remote system for the purpose of metadata harvesting.

Let's click on Catalog & Marketplace and then Metadata Extractions.

Click "+" to create a new remote system.

And now select the newly introduced entry "SAP BW/4HANA"

Select the Live Connection you just created before and then create this new remote connection.

Now we can edit the remote connection you just created to specify which Info Areas and sub info areas we want harvest the metadata from.

You can also switch to the Source Systems for information to see which source systems are involved in the retrieved metadata.

From then, we can synchronize the extraction of the metadata or define a scheduling job as usual with any of the remote systems the SAP Datasphere catalog can connect to.

The metadata for all the objects associated to the selected Info Areas will be available in the catalog. This includes the following type of containers or assets:

  • Info Areas
  • Source Systems
  • Advanced Datastore Objects
  • Info Objects
  • Data Source
  • Info Sources
  • Composite Providers
  • Transformations
  • BW Query Elements
  • Open ODS Views
  • Open Hub Destinations
  • Data Transfer Processes
  • Aggregation Levels

Exploring SAP BW/4HANA metadata

We can now explore the metadata available in the catalog from the BW/4HANA system we synced with by clicking "Catalog & Marketplace" and then "Search".

We can select the container that corresponds to our BW/4HANA system we harvested the metadata from.

And then expand and navigate through the different Info Areas or Source Systems as containers.

You can also filter by the different types of assets available

Click "Show More" to see the entire list of supported objects that can help you refine what you are searching for.

Opening any of the asset gives access to the technical metadata as well as the column details. Any of the existing feature to enrich the assets with business metadata such as descriptions, business glossary terms, KPIs, and Classification Tags can be used to further enhance the metadata for the SAP BW/4HANA harvested metadata as described in this blog.

Lineage and Impact Analysis graph is available for any of the assets from BW/4HANA when applicable which allows to understand how the objects are created and how they are used, but also offers easy navigation to other assets in the catalog.

By leveraging SAP Datasphere catalog with metadata harvested from SAP BW/4HANA, organizations can ensure that their data is not only accessible but also meaningful and reliable, driving informed decision-making and powering advanced analytics and AI initiatives.

What’s Next?

We will continue to extend the coverage of the SAP metadata we can harvest to continuously support organizations on their data governance journey.

I also want to share some additional resources for you around SAP Datasphere: 

  • Join SAP Datasphere community to see what’s new, ask questions, share your feedback, and more. 
  • SAP Datasphere product overview  
  • Documentation for SAP Datasphere catalog

entry.title: SAP BDC Ecosystem
entry.content:
By now you may have got a good understanding of SAP BDC components from my earlier blogs.

Now let's try to see how it all fits together.

 

 

At the first level we start with the data repository source. It may be an SAP system (like SAP S/4, Success Factor, SAP BW etc. )  or any non-SAP system.

Customers struggle a lot in heterogeneous system where data is stored in multiple different data storage systems. This data is vital for reporting.

 

For the data-driven modern organisations, having convenient access to all the necessary data in a specific and centralised location is important. Easy, convenient access ensures that data resources are always available at a moment’s notice, easing the process for you and allowing you to conduct all operations. 

 

With SAP BDC, various in-built SAP provided connectors available which we can use to connect to SAP as well as non-SAP systems and integrate them as a source of information i.e. transactional & master data.

SAP BDC system resides in SAP BTP platform similar to SAP Datasphere tenant sub-accounts currently. 

You will have a separate SAP Datasphere instance inside your SAP BDC environment.

SAP Datasphere is the evolution of the SAP data warehouse(earlier SAP BW) solution in the cloud, combining capabilities from SAP Data Warehouse Cloud with its agile enterprise data warehouse, self-service data modelling and SAP Data Intelligence Cloud with its data orchestration, lineage, quality, among other capabilities.

In data integration projects, a lot of time is spent trying to recreate context that has been lost during data replication, especially when getting data from the database layer belonging to heterogeneous storage systems.

With SAP BDC, customers will be able to bring all the structured and non-structured data under single umbrella in business data fabric.

This simplifies complex data landscapes and delivers meaningful data to every data consumer, be it Data architect, business user or a decision maker – it takes the benefits and value further by keeping the business logic and application context from data intact.

For each of the source systems, SAP has provided ready-to-use data products which can be found in SAP BDC Cockpit.

To use out-of-the-box Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud with third-party data, first browse the available Data Products in the SAP Business Data Cloud Cockpit. Then select and install the one that best meets your requirements before proceeding with integration.

 

 

 

 SAP BDC system eliminates the need to recreate all the business context lost from extracting data - giving business stakeholders and data consumers the ability to accelerate their decision-making with trust and confidence, knowing they always have the complete picture of their data regardless of where it is stored or how it was designed.

 

SAP Data products are combination of curated views & tables, metadata, access control, inbound and outbound interfaces, load capabilities, data lineage etc. which are used by semantic layer in SAP Datasphere by consumption ready data models which can be then used for internal data manipulation and transformation.

 

This data can then be used for

  1. Reporting by SAP Analytics cloud through live data, dashboards and stories
  2. AI/ML capabilities by Databricks for powerful compute and advance analytics
  3. Visualization by intelligent apps for business users to interact with real-time insights securely and intuitively

 

SAP BDC replicates source data into Datasphere object store once; downstream consumers access it from there.

With use of delta Sharing , Databricks gets real-time access to data without duplication saving storage space and associated costs.

 

 

 

All in all, SAP BDC is built upon a robust stack of integrated components, each playing a vital role in its functionality.

  • SAP BDC combines SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and their capabilities into one fully managed SaaS solution for all data and analytics needs.
  • It seamlessly integrates mission-critical SAP data with third-party sources—without losing business context or requiring constant extraction.
  • SAP transforms and harmonizes business data within a hyperscaler environment, ensuring high-quality, ready-to-use data across the board.
  • Prebuilt SAP Business Data Cloud Intelligent Applications deliver instant, AI-powered business insights with minimal setup, accelerating decision-making and innovation.

 

Ultimately, SAP BDC helps organizations:

  • Streamline operations with advanced data pipelines
  • Accelerate innovation through AI and predictive analytics
  • Improve agility by enabling teams to respond to change quickly
  • Drive business growth by turning data into a competitive advantage

 

Happy Learning!

 

Swati Gawade-Shingade.

Cognizant technology Solutions.

You may also go through below blogs

SAP BDC for Dummies - SAP Community

SAP BDC Key Features - SAP Community

Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products - SAP Community

entry.title: Tim Koster
entry.content:
Tim

  • Netherlands
  • SAP Mentor since 2025
  • Follow Tim on LinkedIn

Tim has been deeply involved with SAP Datasphere since its early days as SAP Data Warehouse Cloud, working directly with SAP Product Management teams to influence the product roadmap at some of Europe's largest implementations. He co-hosts the Dutch BI Podcast and is a frequent speaker at SAP events throughout the Netherlands, including SITnl, VNSG, and SAP Innovation Day. Tim actively contributes to the SAP Community through blogs and discussions and has developed tools for the SAP Datasphere community.

Topics of interest: SAP Datasphere, SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Databricks, AI within the SAP ecosystem

Tim, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

Working with SAP Datasphere over the years, I've had the opportunity to collaborate with Product Management teams and contribute to various discussions around product development. These experiences have shown me how valuable it is when the community and SAP work together to shape solutions that truly meet customer needs. The SAP Mentor program feels like a natural next step to deepen this collaboration.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

Share your real-world experiences - both successes and challenges. The community learns most from authentic stories. Engage directly with Product Management through forums, events, and feedback channels. Your voice as a practitioner matters immensely.

Stay curious about emerging technologies. The SAP landscape is evolving rapidly. Most importantly, contribute in whatever way feels authentic to you - whether it's writing blogs, speaking at events, or asking thoughtful questions in forums. Get involved, exchange ideas with other SAP professionals, and learn from different approaches. This collaborative learning makes us all better.

entry.title: BW-Like Authorizations in Datasphere (DSP)
entry.content:
Basics:
In DSP, authorizations are managed at the space level, not for individual Data Builder objects like in BW (e.g., InfoCubes (RSINFOCUBE), InfoObjects (RSIOBJNM), …). Privileges grant access to specific tasks (creating Data Builder objects, translations, running flows, etc.), but not to individual flows or objects themselves.

While privileges can restrict access to unexposed views within a space, developers (with the "modeler" role) retain access. Therefore, this access control method is only effective in Test/Production systems. For exposed views or Analytical Models, you must implement Data Access Control (DACs).

Application Component, InfoArea, Cube/Composite, ADSO, InfoObject, …:

Simulating InfoArea RSINFOAREA or specific Provider RSINFOCUBE, RSIOBJNM in a space is not possible without high development and maintenance costs. One should create spaces for each Info Area and provide full access to all objects in a space.  (Architectural Proposal/suggestion details in this blog:  https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/sap-datasphere-architecture-and-security-concept/ba-p/13702030)

Possible work around would be:

  • Create DAC: User to DSP / Builder Object.
  • Mandatory usage of the DAC in each persisted Object (persistency constraint).
  • DAC tables must be maintained in a different space (to avoid developers changing the authorizations).
  • Developers must not have Data Warehouse Data Access Control Privilege assigned.
  • Each DAC relevant / Builder object would have to have the Security Field included.

However, con is very high maintenance costs. Therefore: RSINFOAREA, RSAPPLNM, RSINFOCUBE/S_RS_HCPR, RSIOBJNM, … should be replaced with access to a specific InfoArea-like Space.

RSZCOMPTP / Query:

cannot be done in DSP at all. Exposed Views or AMs are consumed in SAC as Stories or Applications (or 3rd party tools, this blog describes SAC only).

In SAC the Teams would be our entry point simulating the InfoArea, Cube/Composite access. Teams allow access to specific Folders, Stories, Applications and group SAC Roles providing permissions for specific tasks / objects.

In case the SAC is used like Query-Designer, without Planning features, the setup is straightforward. Just create a Team for each InfoArea allowing the users to execute the Stories.

 BIAUTH / Data Authorizations:

  • Authorization data must be transferred to DACs.  Example: 0PLANT, 0COMP_CODE (this can be done automatically from BW/4: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/introducing-remote-authorizations-from-sap-bw-4hana-for-sap-datasphere/ba-p/13518819 (DSP already allows wildcards and hierarchy nodes). 
  • Alternative is to download the data manually into CSVs und use the CSVs as basis to the DAC tables.
  • Assign the DACs into model-views/AMs and thus protect the data.

If you follow the central space approach, where data persistency is done in the central space and the InfoArea-like space just consumes shared views, you can implement DACs in every Builder object.

entry.title: Session 5 Recap & Highlights - Planning Your Transition Paths to SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Let's review the key insights from our session on 'Planning your transition path to SAP Business Data Cloud'.

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) marks a transformative approach to enterprise data management and utilization. This comprehensive SaaS platform centralizes and governs SAP data assets while integrating effortlessly with external data sources. BDC is designed to tackle the increasing complexity of today's data environments and meet the critical demand for AI-enabled, real-time analytical capabilities.

 

Customer Needs Driving the Transition

Organizations face several critical challenges that SAP BDC is designed to address:
Data Accessibility and Context: Companies struggle with extracting data from SAP systems while maintaining business semantics and context. When data is moved to external platforms, valuable business meaning is often lost, requiring significant time and resources to rebuild .

AI and Analytics Acceleration: Modern businesses need high-quality, AI-ready data to drive reliable and accurate artificial intelligence applications. The traditional approach of fragmented data silos impedes innovation and limits the potential for advanced analytics .

Simplified Data Landscape: Multiple tools, manual processes, and inconsistent data preparation tasks slow the development of advanced analytics and AI capabilities. Organizations seek a unified platform that can eliminate these inefficiencies.

Real-time Insights: The demand for faster time-to-insights requires modern infrastructure capable of supporting real-time decision-making processes across all business functions.

 

Adoption Journey and Transition Approaches
SAP has defined a structured approach to BDC adoption that allows organizations to progress at their own pace while preserving existing investments. The transition follows a three-phase methodology: Lift, Shift, and Innovate.

 

Evolving Beyond SAP Data and Analytics Portfolio

SAP customers utilizing systems like SAP BW (Business Warehouse), SAP HANA, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud are increasingly seeking pathways to modernize their data environments. The introduction of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) represents a major shift, offering organizations an integrated, cloud-native platform capable of unifying data from SAP and non-SAP sources, enabling advanced analytics, and powering AI-driven insights in real time.

Migrating from SAP BW and SAP HANA
Many enterprises have long relied on SAP BW for critical reporting and data warehousing needs. However, with SAP BW 7.5 reaching end of mainstream maintenance in 2027, businesses are tasked with deciding between maintaining aging systems or embracing cloud-ready solutions. BDC allows organizations to lift and shift their existing BW environments—including critical data models and business logic—directly into the cloud, often through SAP BW/4HANA private cloud edition. This preserves past investments while immediately unlocking scalable data products, improved governance, and seamless integration with SAP Datasphere and Databricks for analytics and AI scenarios. SAP HANA customers similarly benefit from BDC’s cloud-native architecture, which supports both structured and unstructured data, and offers scalable compute and flexible storage options for modern workloads.
 

 

Transitioning from SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud
With SAP BDC, customers currently operating SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud can expect a smooth, phased transition. BDC unifies these solutions into a single environment, streamlining workflows and reducing silos. Organizations leverage their existing data pipelines and analytics use cases - with features like zero-copy integration and data product generators - while quickly gaining access to enhanced AI, collaboration tools, and cross-platform interoperability. This means existing assets and semantic models in SAP Datasphere or Analytics Cloud can be retained and enriched rather than rebuilt, simplifying governance and accelerating time to value.
 
 
Key Benefits and Approach
The move to SAP Business Data Cloud is designed to minimize disruption. SAP provides a structured, stepwise migration methodology focused on:
  • Data Continuity: Preserving historical data and business rule integrity.
  • Operational Stability: Supporting parallel operations and robust fallback options during migration.
  • Capability Development: Offering training and resources so teams can maximize the value of BDC features.
  • Unified Data Governance: Centralizing oversight and compliance across all SAP and external data sources.

 

Strategic Planning Resources

It provides clear, concise answers to the most common technical and strategic questions architects encounter, such as how BDC unifies and governs SAP and third-party data, supports semantic modeling, and aligns with existing SAP environments like SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP BW.

It provides a centralized platform where architects can explore missions, reference architectures, and best practice guides tailored to the unique challenges of data platform modernization. Through curated use cases and real-world implementation patterns, the Discovery Center clarifies how SAP BDC unifies SAP and non-SAP data, streamlines data integration, and supports advanced analytics and AI. Architects can leverage solution diagrams, architecture blueprints, and tools in the Discovery Center to design resilient, scalable BDC environments.

The SAP Architecture Centre is a strategic hub for enterprise architects navigating the transition to SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). It offers in-depth reference architectures, solution diagrams, and best practice guides specifically designed to address the complex requirements of modern data management and cloud adoption.

 

Implementation Support

The Accelerator Hub offers immediate access to an extensive library of ready-to-use integration components, APIs, and architectural templates that simplify the creation and deployment of cloud data solutions designed for SAP's dynamic platform ecosystem. This centralized resource enables architects to rapidly identify, assess, and test APIs along with Data Product and Data Package elements specifically for S/4HANA Private Cloud environments, significantly reducing the challenges commonly encountered during cloud migration and hybrid integration projects.
 

 

The SAP Roadmap Explorer is a powerful tool that helps enterprise architects plan their transition to SAP Business Data Cloud with greater clarity and confidence. It provides a clear view of current features and future innovations related to BDC, allowing architects to understand what’s available now and what’s coming soon. This helps them align technical plans with business goals and make informed decisions about timing, dependencies, and integration points. Overall, the SAP Roadmap Explorer gives architects the insight they need to design a well-structured, future-ready path to SAP Business Data Cloud.

 

Technology Capability Model in LeanIX

 

LeanIX’s Technology Capability Model (TCM) provides a framework for:
  • Current state assessment of existing technology landscapes
  • Target architecture design for future state planning
  • Transformation roadmap development with clear milestones and dependencies
  • Governance structure establishment for implementation oversight

 

Next Steps and Way Forward
Immediate Actions
1. Assess current SAP BW environment using SAP’s free assessment service (SAP Migration Assessment)
2. Evaluate transition readiness through the BDC Discovery Workshop
3. Develop stakeholder alignment across business and IT teams
Medium-term Planning
1. Design target architecture using LeanIX and SAP Architecture Center resources
2. Create detailed migration roadmap with phased approach
3. Establish governance framework for ongoing transformation management
Long-term Vision
1. Implement AI/ML capabilities through Databricks integration
2. Adopt Intelligent Applications for accelerated business value
3. Optimize data product economy for reusable, scalable data assets

The transition to SAP Business Data Cloud represents more than a technical migration - it’s a strategic transformation that positions organizations for the AI-driven future of business. With SAP’s structured approach of Land, Expand, and Adopt, organizations can preserve existing investments while gaining access to cutting-edge capabilities. The comprehensive ecosystem of resources, tools, and professional services ensures that organizations have the support needed to navigate this critical transformation successfully.
With proper planning, stakeholder alignment, and strategic execution, the move to SAP Business Data Cloud can unlock significant business value and competitive advantage in an increasingly data-driven marketplace.
 

Note: Slides from the session and the recording would be only available to the registered attendees. So if you have not registered, please register now using the link - Architecting Your SAP Business Data Cloud Journey – From Data to Intelligence!

 

Special thanks to...

@PaulKurchina  @Timo  @Gaurish-Dessai  @ralph_richter  @NaveenDumpa

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud: オブジェクトストア 入門編
entry.content:
はじめに

SAP Business Data CloudではSAPのビジネスアプリケーション間のデータを共通のデータモデルとしてデータセットおよびセマンティック（項目名の用語や意味合い）を整え、SAP データプロダクトとして提供します。また、お客様独自の要件やデータソースに対してはカスタムデータプロダクトを作成することができます。

これによりSAPアプリケーションのデータだけでなく、SAP以外のデータも整備しAIエージェントに必要なデータとして提供できるため、ダッシュボードでデータを可視化するだけではなく、Jouleを使いながら対話形式でさらなるデータ分析の深堀やインサイトを得るなどデータ活用の幅を広げることができます。

そのような独自要件に則ったカスタムデータプロダクトの作成はSAP Datasphereの機能を用いて行いますが、本ブログではカスタムデータプロダクトの作成を行う領域にあたるSAP Datasphereのオブジェクトストアに関してご紹介いたします。

概要

オブジェクトストアは安価な受信ステージングエリアで大量のデータをロードおよび準備することを目的としており、以下の前提があります。

  • ビュー、データフロー、データアクセス制御、分析モデル、インテリジェントルックアップ、E/R モデルを作成したり、ビジネスビルダを使用したりすることはできません。

  • CSV ファイル、エンティティ、リモートテーブル、または通貨換算テーブルはインポートできません。SAP HANA スマートデータアクセスおよび SAP HANA スマートデータインテグレーションは、ストレージタイプが SAP HANA データベース (ディスクおよびインメモリ) のスペースでのみ使用されるため、適用されません 。

また、データは複製フロー、BWデータプロダクトジェネレーターを介してロードすることができます。

その他オブジェクトストアに関する詳細情報は以下もご確認下さい。

オブジェクトストアでのデータの取得および準備 
3538038 - SAP Datasphere オブジェクトストアの重要な考慮事項

本ブログでは接続を介したS/4HANAなどの外部システムから複製フローによりデータをオブジェクトストアへロードする方法をご紹介いたします。

  1. オブジェクトストアスペースの作成
  2. 複製フローの作成
  3. マージタスクの実行
  4. スペースへの共有

オブジェクトストアの作成

管理者ロールを持つユーザーは安価なステージングエリアで大量のデータをロードおよび準備することを目的としたオブジェクトストアにスペースを作成することができます。

オブジェクトスペースの作成は「スペース管理」＞「作成」より可能です。

スペース名やストレージタイプを選択します。

オブジェクトストアスペースの作成には「SAP HANAデータレイクファイル」を選択し「作成」します。

複製フローの作成

複製フローの作成・実行により空のターゲットテーブルが作成されます。この時点ではデータはターゲットテーブルへはロードされません。

（複製フローに関してはこちらのブログシリーズも併せてご確認ください：複製フローPart１: 複製フロー概要）

*注：オブジェクトストアの使用にはいくつかの考慮事項があります。例えば、複製フローの作成にはデルタ抽出可能なソースのみに対応している等いくつかの考慮事項があるため、次のSAP Note より詳細をご確認下さい。3538038 - SAP Datasphere オブジェクトストアの重要な考慮事項

マージタスクの実行

複製フローは、ターゲットテーブル の受信バッファにデータファイルを書き込みます。この受信バッファからローカルテーブル へのデータ更新を処理してデータを表示するには、①データ統合モニタよりマージタスクの実行あるいは➁タスクチェーンの作成によるマージタスクの実行が必要です。

①データ統合モニタよりマージタスクの実行

「データ統合モニタ」を表示すると以下のようにローカルテーブルにレコードが挿入されていないことが分かります。

画面右の「>」よりローカルテーブルの詳細を開きます。

「テーブルをマージ」よりマージタスクの実行が可能です。

また、以下のように日時や週次でのスケジュールを設定することも可能です。

➁タスクチェーンの作成によるマージタスクの実行

アクティビティに「マージ」を選択しタスクチェーンの作成・実行をします。

「①データ統合モニタよりマージタスクの実行」あるいは「➁タスクチェーンの作成によるマージタスクの実行」により受信バッファからローカルテーブルにデータが書き込まれ、レコードが挿入されます。

スペースへの共有

オブジェクトスペース内では変換フローを用いてテーブルの結合など変換を適用することができ、その後テーブルをスペースと共有することでフローやビュー、また分析モデルのソースとして利用することができます。

オブジェクトストアより共有されたテーブルをソースとしてモデリングや分析モデルの作成、SAP Analytics Cloudでのデータ参照も可能ですが、データフローや変換フローを用いてスペース内でデータを保持することでよりパフォーマンスを高く利用が可能です。

さいごに

最後までご覧いただきありがとうございました！

以下に関連する情報を記載していますので、併せてご確認ください。

  • オブジェクトストアでのデータの取得および準備 
  • 3538038 - SAP Datasphere オブジェクトストアの重要な考慮事項

複製フロー解説ブログシリーズ：

  • 複製フローPart１: 複製フロー概要
  • 複製フローPart2 : デルタキャプチャと変換フロー

entry.title: New: Value Analytics for SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Upon the release of the Q2 2025 SAP Analytics Cloud Content and SAP Datasphere Content package, a new page has been added to the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement story that is entirely dedicated towards SAP Fieldglass KPIs. This is the first of many updates to the tool that will expand its functionality far beyond SAP Ariba Procurement, allowing companies to analyze spend at a wider visibility than ever before.

The new page in SAP Value Analytics for Procurement provides a big picture summary of SAP Fieldglass spend categories. Just like the other stories, users are presented with a clean and simplified view of data from select KPIs. Companies that choose to operationalize this new page may easily gain insights on their SAP Fieldglass data, including:

  • The influence of workforce management efficiency on overall revenue
  • Costs incurred by ensuring projects & hiring processes stay compliant
  • The financial impact of maintaining a quality workforce

If providing users with a way to further operationalize SAP Fieldglass data in a comprehensive analysis of spend piques your interest, please continue reading for more information on how to activate the new SAP Fieldglass page in SAP Value Analytics for Procurement.

1. SAP Analytics Cloud - Strategic Spend Overview

After opening the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement story in SAP Analytics Cloud, navigate to the page entitled “Fieldglass”. Along with the title, the top module contains a summary of spend related to high-value KPIs in SAP Fieldglass. A dimension module with a "Date Range" filtering option appears below the title module, followed by three data visualization modules, entitled “Cost Savings”, “Compliance”, and “Process Improvement” to represent the major categories of Fieldglass Transactions.

SAP Fieldglass page view in SAP Analytics Cloud

2. SAP Datasphere Integration for SAP Value Analytics for Procurement

Initiating the activation of the SAP Fieldglass page requires some manual configuration. After the necessary reports are built in Fieldglass, the user must download them in CSV format and upload them into SAP Datasphere. All other relevant objects can be found in the SAP_CONTENT space.

As of Q2 2025, the images below are the most updated views of the integration architecture and the SAP Datasphere objects included in the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement package.

Integration architecture (updated to include SAP Fieldglass assets)

SAP Datasphere objects view (updated to Include SAP Fieldglass objects)

As a reminder, the following naming conventions have been used:
SM -> Supplier Management
SC -> Sourcing & Contracts
BI -> Buying & Invoicing
FG -> Fieldglass

The data modeling for the SAP Fieldglass page follows the layered approach of content development in SAP Datasphere. Here, the set up for SAP Fieldglass Project analysis is used as the example, the photo below describing the direction of the model layers:

SAP Fieldglass data model workflow

The Integration Layer (IL) contains the local table SAP Fieldglass: Project (LT) (SAP_Fieldglass_SRC_Project_MA), which was created in a manual file upload, as mentioned previously. In addition, this layer also includes the abstracting view, SAP Fieldglass: Project (IL) (SAP_PROC_FG_IL_Project), which adds data specific to the realm.

The Harmonization Layer (HL), SAP Fieldglass: Project (HL) (SAP_PROC_FG_HL_ProjectSQL), acts as the Fact View that combines Fieldglass project data with the Date Grid view.

Finally, the Reporting Layer (RL) uses the Analytic Model SAP Fieldglass: Project (RL) (SAP_PROC_FG_RL_Project) to define additional calculated measures and expose the data to the SAP Fieldglass page in SAP Analytics Cloud.

3. Content Documentation

Thank you for reading this SAP Community article!

To view the blog post on the original release of SAP Value Analytics for SAP Ariba Procurement in Q2 2024, please view ‘Maximize Value with Value Analytics for SAP Ariba’ by @SimonKranig.

For further instructions on configuring SAP Value Analytics for Procurement, please view this discovery mission.

More details on the SAP Fieldglass content package for SAP Value Analytics for Procurement can be found on this SAP Help page.

Have questions and want to share with other users? Feel free to post a question in the community:
SAP Community > SAP Analytics Cloud
SAP Community > SAP Datasphere

entry.title: SAP Datasphere Replication Flow Logs: Monitoring & Insights
entry.content:
Introduction

Replication Flow is one of the key artifcate to integrate data from SAP and NON-SAP source system to Datasphere or outside world.

In this blog, we’ll s see how to track Replication Flow execution by accessing key metadata tables and diagnostic views within SAP Datasphere.

 

Step by Step Implementation

 

1) Create a  Database User Group

Begin by creating a global DB user to secure connectivity with underling SAP HANA Database.

Ensure you note down the Host, Port, Username and Password.

Link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/9f804b8efa8043539289f42f372c4862/1097a470be40432e89f91288bdc14378.html 

2) Setup SAP HANA Connection

Establish a connection in your Datasphere space using:

  • Host
  • Port
  • Username
  • Password

This connection enables access to remote tables and metadata views critical for diagnostics.

3) Access Replication Metadata:

Go to Data builder ->  Import Remote table -> select SAP HANA connection.

serach for the space_name$TEC schema (space_name is your space name where Replication flow is created), under that schema import the REPLICATIONFLOW_RUN_DETAILS table.

4) Access Task Metadata:

Get all TASK Related Data from DWC_GLOBAL schema and view TASK_LOCKS_V_EXT

  • Import remote table
  • select SAP HANA connection
  • select DWC_GLOBAL schema
  • select TASK_LOGS_V_EXT view

5) Merge the data from both tables:

Join/Union both the tables and get all the required fields as per the requirement.

Conclusion

By building a model on top of these two tables, you can view all the metadata related to your Replication Flows. This helps you track key details like execution time, status, and any errors. So if something goes wrong, you'll be able to quickly identify and understand the issue.

Thanks

Vikas Parmar

SAP Datasphere  SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering
entry.content:
This blog post is a joint work of @Nektarios_Vasileiou33 and @BlazZabukovec .

Picture 1: SAP Analytics Cloud demo story example - Dashboard design by Daniel Davis

Motivation

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognising these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organisational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organisations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support – going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering (THIS BLOG POST)

  2. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?

  3. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world

  4. Planning & Analysis in the context of SAP BDC

  5. Move BPC and BW-IP into SAP BDC

  6. Real-time steering with LIVE planning

  7. PaPM use cases

  8. Self – service analytics and real time business steering

  9. Business steering powered by AI agents

  10. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting

  11. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

CHALLENGES

The current global market situation is characterised by heightened volatility and uncertainty, driven by factors such as geopolitical tensions, inflationary pressures and rapid technological advancements. In this dynamic environment businesses face significant challenges like supply chain disruptions, rising and uncontrolled operational costs and the need for digital transformation to remain competitive.

Obviously, there is no one-size-fits-all solution to every challenge, but adopting a data-driven decision-making process provides significant advantages that can help organizations navigate complexities and respond more effectively to market dynamics. By relying on data to drive decisions, businesses can achieve greater accuracy and insight, which helps in identifying trends, understanding customer behaviours, and optimising operations. This approach enables companies to be more agile and responsive to changing conditions.

Every leader today feels the weight of growing complexity. CFOs balancing growth and profitability. CHROs managing talent in an evolving workforce. CIOs modernising IT while keeping innovation alive.

Picture 2: Challenges by CXO persona

But the true challenge lies in how these functions are increasingly interconnected. When one part of the business is disrupted, whether it’s a supply chain issue or a talent gap, the ripple effects are felt everywhere. To succeed, businesses need more than solutions for individual challenges, businesses need a way to align every function and unlock collective power.

Like Aristotle (apparently) once said: “THE WHOLE IS GREATER THAN THE SUM OF ITS PARTS”

Today’s complexity demands more than incremental fixes and silo apps/solutions. If we want to have benefits from AI and systems of agents collaborating across all functions, we need to have a solid foundation, where we can seamlessly combine applications, data, insights and AI into one ecosystem.

Just picture this example around Financial Planning (incl. forecasting & simulation), where we can develop a comprehensive financial snapshot while automating workflow tasks through agentic AI.

Picture 3: Forecasting & Simulation use case evolution

This is where we bring together all relevant data, like revenues, expenses, also across different scenarios, like actuals, plan & forecast. We also integrate all relevant external data, like different macro-economic KPIs, external market research data., etc. Based on identified key drivers/influencers of our business, we are going to define and perform different planning/forecasting scenarios. In the next step we are going to simulate and analyse impact of external drivers like inflation rate on our performance and identify the areas that will be impacted. Specialised analytics agent can propose potential mitigation strategies, like targeted promotions to drive customer demand, that can be further assessed & analysed. Based on this information we can decide for a certain course of actions that can be triggered by system of agents.

Picture 4: Risk analysis & mitigation strategies delivered by agentic AI

We can say with great confidence that our customers are not working in the area of visualising their data and that’s why SAP is also not in the business of visualising our customer’s data (even though we can do this is in a great way), but we are in a business of enabling the “Insights to Action” framework which is exactly what I have illustrated in the use case around financial planning powered by agentic AI.

Organizations striving to make data-driven decisions and a proper, also AI powered jump from insights to action, encounter several significant challenges. One major obstacle is seamlessly integrating data across various systems to extract valuable business insights. Additionally, ensuring data quality and integrity is crucial to maintaining trust in the decision-making process. Furthermore, building a comprehensive data foundation is essential for supporting the deployment of AI-based applications. Addressing these challenges requires robust data management strategies and innovative solutions to harness the full potential of data for valuable decision-making.

SAP's STRATEGY

To tackle these challenges, SAP developed the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to provide cloud services that empower organizations in navigating the complexities of data management and business steering process. SAP BDC serves as a unified platform, providing the necessary agility for effective business steering. SAP BDC offers a semantically rich, unified data environment that enhances operational efficiency and strategic decision-making capabilities. By centralising key business data from SAP and non-SAP sources into a unified semantic layer, SAP BDC unlocks insights, advanced analytics, and AI capabilities, empowering businesses to drive intelligent growth and innovation.

Picture 5: SAP Business Suite

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is a fully managed Software as a Service (SaaS) solution that unifies and governs all SAP data while seamlessly connecting with third-party data. The solution combines the capabilities of SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse, along with managed SAP Databricks. SAP BDC includes curated business-ready data products from SAP line of business applications leveraged by business-ready Intelligent Applications providing line-of-business leaders the context needed to make impactful decisions.

Picture 6: High level overview of SAP BDC services

Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud:

SAP Datasphere: As the foundational element of SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere provides a streamlined environment for data integration, warehousing, and governance. It features flexible integrated data tiering—comprising object, disk-based, and in-memory storage—ensuring a cost-effective persistence layer. Additionally, it offers sophisticated tools for analytical data modeling, transformation, and integration, enabling organizations to extract valuable insights and foster business innovation. Users can also utilize the framework to develop their own data products.

SAP Analytics Cloud: This component delivers cutting-edge analytics and planning capabilities while providing real-time insights powered by AI and machine learning. It integrates seamlessly with SAP Datasphere to offer a unified data analysis experience.

SAP Databricks: Through SAP's partnership with Databricks, data science capabilities are significantly enhanced. This collaboration facilitates advanced analytics and data science operations on both SAP and non-SAP data. Key features include ML Flows for machine learning operations, Mosaic AI for model training and serving, and Notebooks equipped with coding assistants and visualizations. The serverless Spark offerings aim to simplify big data processing, while replication-free access to SAP data products and integration with the Unity Catalogue further enrich the experience.

Intelligent Applications and Data Products: SAP Business Data Cloud emphasizes Intelligent Applications and SAP-managed Data Products. These ready-to-use, standardized business data objects and applications are managed by SAP, reducing the effort needed to build and operate analytical and data science applications. They promote data consistency and reusability, serving as modular, reusable assets for analytical models or AI/ML and planning workflows.

Unified Semantic Layer: Central to SAP Business Data Cloud is the unified semantic model, which standardizes data definitions across SAP and non-SAP systems. It offers simplified zero-copy data access via a standardized delta-share interface, supporting cross-domain analytics and AI applications. Additionally, it features a centralized cross-application catalog for data products and Intelligent Applications.

SAP BW: is integrated into SAP BDC, allowing SAP BW objects to be onboarded as data products. The SAP BW data products can be integrated in SAP Databricks to enable advanced analytics and data science use cases.

BUSINESS VALUE

SAP BDC delivers significant business value in the context of business steering, particularly within planning and analytics use cases. 

Enhanced Decision-Making: SAP BDC revolutionises decision-making by providing real-time access to integrated data. This SAP Analytics Cloud capability ensures that business leaders receive accurate and immediate insights, empowering them to make informed and strategic decisions. With this enhanced decision-making capacity, organizations can effectively anticipate market trends, adjust their strategies in response to evolving conditions, and maintain a competitive edge in their respective industries.

Comprehensive Data Integration: At the heart of SAP BDC is its ability to seamlessly integrate data from multiple sources, both SAP and non-SAP systems. This integration creates a unified view of the organisation's data landscape, supporting precise planning and predictive forecasting. By breaking down data silos and ensuring a holistic perspective, SAP BDC enables businesses to gain comprehensive insights into their operations and make well-rounded decisions. The data holistic perspective is fundamental for organizations to unleash AI across the entire data ecosystem.

Scalable Analytics and Planning Capabilities: One of the standout features of SAP BDC is its scalable analytics and planning capabilities. It allows businesses to conduct extensive analyses and simulations, uncovering valuable insights that aid in tailoring forecasts to specific scenarios. Whether it's understanding customer behavior or predicting market shifts, SAP Analytics Cloud robust analytics and planning capabilities in combination with SAP Databricks empower organizations to make data-driven predictions with unmatched precision and confidence.

Improved Efficiency and Agility: SAP BDC streamlines data integration and analytics processes, significantly enhancing efficiency and agility within organizations. By automating these crucial processes, leveraging data management features in SAP Datasphere, analytics in SAP Analytics Cloud and AI/ML workflows in SAP Databricks, it cuts down the time and effort needed for data preparation and analysis (replication free access of data and zero-copy). This efficiency allows teams to redirect their focus from operational concerns to strategic steering, driving more meaningful business results in less time.

Facilitated Innovation: Leveraging cutting-edge technologies such as artificial intelligence and machine learning, SAP BDC promotes innovation within organizations. Its cloud-based infrastructure ensures that businesses have access to the latest advancements, encouraging the exploration of new and innovative business models. This focus on facilitated innovation helps companies remain at the forefront of industry trends and continuously evolve their offerings.

Consistency in Data Governance: Ensuring data integrity and consistency is a critical component of SAP BDC's value proposition. The platform offers comprehensive data governance and quality management, providing reliable data integrity across planning and analytics activities. With consistent data definitions and governance, businesses can achieve accurate reporting and foster alignment across various departments, leading to cohesive planning strategies.

Seamless Collaboration: SAP BDC enhances collaboration by centralising data accessibility and sharing. Data Cataloguing, Data Sharing and Collaboration capabilities foster improved teamwork among departments and enables synchronised planning efforts and a guided steering process. With shared insights and aligned goals, teams can work together more effectively, driving unified strategies and achieving common objectives that benefit the entire organisation.

Strategic Resource Allocation: Through its predictive analytics and planning capabilities SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Databricks, SAP BDC enables organizations to allocate resources more strategically. By delivering actionable insights, businesses can optimize operations, improve resource allocation, and enhance overall performance. This strategic approach ensures that resources are used efficiently to achieve maximum impact, driving profound business success.

Future-Proofing Autonomous Business Steering: By harnessing SAP AI agents within the trusted SAP BDC data foundation, the planning and business steering process is transformed from a static, periodic exercise into a dynamic, proactive function. These AI-driven insights empower companies to swiftly assess the potential impacts of various strategic options and make decisive actions. This approach allows businesses to anticipate market changes and respond efficiently, making strategic adjustments with confidence and precision.

CONCLUSION

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) stands as a vital tool for organisations striving to enhance their decision-making capabilities, align strategic objectives, and navigate the complexities of modern business landscapes. In the era of AI, organizations require scalable and efficient data architectures to manage growing volumes of data and extract actionable insights leveraging advanced analytics, planning and machine learning capabilities. As we embark on this informative blog series, we invite you to stay tuned for our upcoming posts, where we will delve deeper into the AI, Planning & Analytics functionalities associated with SAP BDC and business steering use cases. Gain insights into how this powerful platform can drive your business forward, optimise operations, and help you achieve your strategic goals with confidence. Join us in exploring the transformative potential of SAP BDC and discover how it can be the catalyst for your organisation's growth and success.

CALL TO ACTION

To deepen your understanding of SAP Business Data Cloud, we invite you to explore the following links:

SAP Business Data Cloud Help

https://help.sap.com/docs/business-data-cloud?locale=en-US

Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud

https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/leveraging-sap-analytics-cloud-functionality-for-enterprise-planning/introducing-sap-business-data-cloud

Positioning SAP Business Data Cloud

https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/positioning-sap-business-data-cloud-1

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in July
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in July

Another month with two great new release deliveries ✨
Learn more in my short top features video in July 2025 on YouTube 📺
In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs.

 

 

My top features in July

 

Data Integration & Connectivity

Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) as Source for Your Replication Flow

After delivering SFTP as a target already in May this year, you can now also use SFTP connections as sources in replication flows to any supported target.

➡️   More information:

  • Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) as Source for Your Replication Flow
  • Generic SFTP Connections

 

Transport Objects Between File Spaces

You can now export objects from and import objects to file spaces, meaning a space based on the embedded object store with file-based artifacts.

➡️   More information

 

Task Chains

New Layout Option in Task Chain Toolbar

The options in the task chain editor toolbar have been re-arranged and a new layout option was added. The new layout option allows you to rearrange the visual display of a task chain on the canvas, from top-to-bottom (the default), or left-to-right.

➡️   More information

 

Connection Type Generic HTTP

With the new connection type, you can connect to external systems and add tasks that are exposed by REST-based APIs to task chains. For this purpose, we have introduced the new API Tasks connection feature, which is supported only for Generic HTTP connections.

➡️   More information

 

Running API Tasks in a Task Chain

The generic HTTP connection is the prerequisite to provide the ability of running tasks in a task chain that use a REST-based API to access external systems.

➡️   More information

 

New Notification Task Object in Task Chains

SAP Datasphere now allows users to set up additional email notification within a task chain, in addition to the notification specified for completion of the entire task chain. Users drag the new Notification Task object to any point in the sequence of tasks run in a task chain and then specify the subject and message for this new email notification. These new notifications use the same recipient list as the email notification maintained at the task chain level.

➡️   More information

 

Self-Service Enhancements

Enable Multi-Availability Zones for SAP HANA Cloud

Use the Enable SAP HANA Multi-Availability Zones option on the Tenant Configuration page to create a synchronous replica of the main system on a system in a different region. The synchronous replica system has a high-availability setup that can take over processing when necessary.

➡️   More information:

  • Configure the Size of Your SAP Datasphere Tenant
  • Creating and Configuring Your SAP Datasphere Tenant

 

Enabling of SAP HANA for SQL data warehousing on Your SAP Datasphere Tenant

Administrators can now create the mapping between their SAP Datasphere tenant and their SAP Business Technology Platform account to enable SAP HANA for SQL data warehousing themselves, rather than needing to raise a ticket. Both environments for Kyma and Cloud Foundry are supported and the same information as previously required for the ticket with Organization ID and Space ID is required to be able to do the instance mapping.

➡️   More information

 

 

 

Webinar Series: Architecting Your SAP BDC Journey – From Data to Intelligence 

There was a great architecture webinar series about SAP Business Data Cloud and various architecture deep dive topics. Thanks to @Gaurish-Dessai, @PaulKurchina, @helmut_grimm and team.

 

Sessions

Speakers

Data Inspired – Successful concepts for data-driven organizations

Paul Kurchina, Dr. Sebastian Wernicke, Helmut Grimm, Gaurish Dessai

Unleash your Data and AI with Irfan Khan and Timo Elliott

Paul Kurchina, Irfan Khan & Timo Elliott

Unpacking SAP Business Data Cloud for Enterprise Architects

Ralph Richter, Gaurish Dessai, Axel Meier, Amogh Umbarkar

Enterprise Architects guide on SAP BW Modernization

Jason Luo & Gaurish Dessai

Planning your Transition Paths to SAP Business Data Cloud

Naveen Dumpa & Jason Luo

SAP Business Data Cloud and Databricks – Stronger Together

Michelle Wiktorsson, Qi Su & Habeebuddin Mohammad

SAP Business Data Cloud & Databricks in Action with Demos

Michelle Wiktorsson, Gaurish Dessai, Rithivika Acharya & Peter Schmidt

SAP BDC Series Wrap up – Insights, Learnings, and the Road Ahead

Paul Kurchina, Ralph Richter, Gaurish Desai, Prakash Nanduri & Timo Elliott

Find the session details, slides and recordings here
➡️   Recordings and Slides from webinar series 'Architecting Your SAP Business Data Cloud Journey'

 

Learning Update

The number of learning opportunities are constantly growing and our colleagues in the learning department have delivered the next milestone with a new instructor-led class about SAP Business Data Cloud. Learn more in the blog from @MarkGreen 
➡️   Learn SAP Business Data Cloud with our new instructor-led class
